description: From Middle English combust (“burnt”), from Old French combust, from Latin combūstus.

adjectives.description: combust (comparative more combust, superlative most combust)

entries.meaning: (astrology) In close conjunction with the sun (so that its astrological influence is "burnt up"), sometimes specified to be within 8 degrees 30'.
examples: Guianerius had a patient could make Latin verses when the moon was combust, otherwise illiterate.

verbs.description: combust (third-person singular simple present combusts, present participle combusting, simple past and past participle combusted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To erupt with enthusiasm or boisterousness.
